subject: configurations: Add ambient virtual sensor to Blyth
commitMessage:
configurations: Add ambient virtual sensor to Blyth

This specifies the parameters for a virtual ambient temperature sensor.
phosphor-virtual-sensor will take this information and create the
virtual sensor.

The virtual sensor takes the readings of three temperature sensors
(TMP275, DPS310, SI7020) on this board to calculate the ambient
temperature. This ambient temperature is published on DBus and will be
used for fan control.

We are using a modified median to calculate this ambient temperature. In
the case of only two valid temperature readings we will use the highest
one - in case the other is too low in error. Otherwise we take the
median value.

Tested: Verified that we can see the config (on p10-bmc on simics):
  busctl introspect xyz.openbmc_project.EntityManager
  /xyz/openbmc_project/inventory/system/board/Blyth_Panel/Ambient_Virtual_Temp

Signed-off-by: Rashmica Gupta <rashmica.g@gmail.com>
Signed-off-by: Matt Spinler <spinler@us.ibm.com>
Change-Id: Id9c4cd22e294bc188f21068fa1babc7cfb3fa5be

Patch Set 15:

Patch Set 15: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 5cd7bbbd83ef8631b99eba86ca532c3ec4c09d89 by Ed Tanous
Some more detail here.  You're adding a pretty good size feature, lets get it documented.
Any associated patches required to test this?
Should type be Median here?
That does seem more consistent with other sensors.
Why is this different than "Name"?
Good question. Will remove this.

"Units" should be the name of the param here, and it should follow something similar to what external sensor did where the user specifies the units of the sensor.  The actual type (ie the dbus path) is an internal detail that we don't want to expose the user to.
Might be a bit pedantic but would "Measurement" or "Category" be more appropriate than "Units"? This is specifying the type of what is being measured rather than the unit the measurement is in.

> Might be a bit pedantic but would "Measurement" or "Category" be more appropriate than "Units"?

Possibly, but the ideal time to discuss that was when external sensor merged, although I'm happy to discuss changing both if that's something you'd like to do, but I'd like to do it outside the context of this patch.  Being consistent here is the most important.

FWIW, I think Units is more descriptive, as it's directly relatable to dbus and indirectly relatable to redfish/ipmi (both of those call it units).

> This is specifying the type of what is being measured rather than the unit the measurement is in.

I'm not following what the difference is.  In our dbus APIs, the "type" is comparable 1:1 with the units being used (generally there's a lookup table between the two).

>  Being consistent here is the most important.
That's fair. 

> I'm not following what the difference is. 
To my brain there is quite a distinction between what we are measuring (temperature, fan tach, etc) and the units we measure in (Celcius, Fahrenheit, Kelvin, RPM, Hz etc). But if we are always using the same units for the type of measurement then I don't really care that much.

See above, I suspect this can just go into type, but if this stays here, we should come up with something better than "Expression"

Also, is there something more descriptive that we can use beyond "modifiedMedian".  It seems like we could better enumerate what is modified  in the name (although I don't know exactly how it differs, so I can't really make suggestions.)

It's essentially a median function except for if there are two valid values and then we use the higher value (one valid value: use it, two: use the higher value, three: use the middle value). I couldn't think of anything better than modifiedMedian, any suggestions?

"Params" isn't very descriptive.  Please take a look at pid loops for how Entity-manager generally represents a list of sensors.  Something like

Sensors: [
    "Sensor1"
    "Sensor2",
]
Ack
This should be the same name as it shows up on line 34 (ie, remove the underscores).
Yeah I guess it should.

This seems like an odd parameter to require at this level;  Why would a user set this to something other than temperature?  More generally, why would the user ever set this to something other than the type of the existing sensor?  If the answer is "they wouldn't" then it doesn't need to be a parameter here.
Agreed.
It looks like there are situations where this could be different to the virtual sensor type/unit. For example a virtual sensor that calculates pressure from altitude sensors.
For these names, lets keep with the existing parameters naming scheme "upper critical", "upper non critical" ect, so we're consistent between config items.
Ok.
MaxReading and MinReading I think is what we use on other sensors, lets be consistent.
Is {min,max}Reading preferred over {min,max}Value? They seem interchangable.
We should be consistent;  Yes, MinReading is the Redfish term (which I mistakenly commented), I think MinValue is what we should use here.
Ok.
I have the actual values to use for these in the virtual_sensor_config.json in meta-ibm
Ack
This is rarely an appropriate range for a temperature.  Generally these are set to -127 and +128, mostly because occasionally servers experience negative temperatures.
I agree with you, however these are the values that the IBM engineers wanted to use to determine if we were going to use a sensor's reading.

MaxValue and MinValue should drive the equivalent properties on Dbus (ie the reading range).  The values of what are "valid" probably need a different property?  Otherwise, these parameters will be doing double duty.

It doesn't seem unreasonable to me to be able to clamp values in configuration for a sensor.  Rashmica are you thinking these are clamp values or that anything outside this range would become an "invalid sensor"?  Both seem like something that should be able to be expressed in configuration but I agree that they are separate concepts.  I'm not sure which you're trying to achieve here.

Right, good point. The intention was that anything outside of those values would be "invalid"/not used. I don't see any existing properties in the schema for something like this. Do you think MaxValidValue and MinValidValue would be appropriate names?

> It doesn't seem unreasonable to me to be able to clamp values in configuration for a sensor.

It doesn't seem unreasonable to me either, but the input limits need to be distinct from the output limits.  Ideally we'd automatically generate the output limits based on our input sensors, but I get that's a few more lines of code you're not wanting to write.



I would start by looking at if CFM and exit air sensor declare anything similar for input validation.  They're doing pretty similar transforms, so we should use the same naming if we can.


> Do you think MaxValidValue and MinValidValue would be appropriate names?

I'd prefer we add something about them being the input.  What about MaxValidInput and MinValidInput?  With that said, please do the above and look to see if exit air or cfm sensors have similar things, and use a similar naming scheme if they do.
They use MaxValue for input tach values and [CFM, ExitAir][Max,Min]Reading for the properties on the output sensors. So I've gone with your suggestion of MaxValidInput.

Did we ever close on how thresholds beyond warning/critical are going to work in entity-manager?  This looks like you're relying on Name still, which is supposed to be an opaque field.  I know I mentioned that on the other review, but I'll mention it here as well just to provide context.


I suspect for the moment dropping the Hard/Soft shutdown from this patchset, and moving it into a later patchset would help this merge faster, then we can discuss later in the greater context of entity-manager, because I suspect all the sensor daemons will need to agree on how we're going to handle these new config items.

I've seen proposed:
Changing severity into an enum.
declaring severities 3-5 for these new features.

I'm not using the name field in code (using severity and direction). I took your previous comments to mean that it doesn't matter what the name field is and so put in names that I thought made it more obvious to someone reading the configuration what these thresholds are used for. I thought I had seen a configuration where names weren't upper/lower [non]critical, but I can't find that anymore so I might have been imagining things :)  


I had assumed that because there were interfaces defined in phosphor-dbus-interfaces for Warning, Critical, PerformanceLoss, SoftShutdown and HardShutdown that we could just use them here. 

I'll change the names back, and add the Hard/Soft shutdowns in separate patches.

> I'm not using the name field in code (using severity and direction).

Ok, that's all I was worried about.  Feel free to leave the names the same if you'd like.

> I took your previous comments to mean that it doesn't matter what the name field is and so put in names that I thought made it more obvious to someone reading the configuration what these thresholds are used for. I thought I had seen a configuration where names weren't upper/lower [non]critical, but I can't find that anymore so I might have been imagining things :)  
> 
> 
> I had assumed that because there were interfaces defined in phosphor-dbus-interfaces for Warning, Critical, PerformanceLoss, SoftShutdown and HardShutdown that we could just use them here. 
> 
> I'll change the names back, and add the Hard/Soft shutdowns in separate patches.
Ok.
I noted this in the schema, but this should be a dbus unit, like "DegreesC".  Please take a look at the ExternalSensor implementation for how this should be done.
Ack
Generally names don't have underscores in them.
Ack
Maybe I missed the comment about it, but what happened to the threshold values added in patch set 7?
Nevermind, they were added in a different commit.
